column119: In your opinion, what are the biggest barriers to promoting student creativity at school? - Open-Ended Response
column130: Have you ever attended courses, workshops or seminars on fostering creativity in your students?
column131: Have you ever attended courses, workshops or seminars on fostering creativity in your students? - Comment
column132: Let us know if you have any other comments. - Open-Ended Response

column82: A process of spatial and mental imagining and exploration to enable personal and colllaborative engagement with materials  and concepts to be realised.
column119: Feeling pressured for time and assumed outcomes in learning processes rather than facilitating diverse strategies for individualised, multi modal and collaborative learning processes.
column131: International INSEA conferences, personal practices and regular participation in SA Art Gallery workshops and Professional development sessions.

column82: Thinking outside the box. Looking at different perspectives and using different strategies for the same problems.
column119: time constraints and curriculum pressures. Very hard to have time to plan creative lessons!

column82: Creativity involves trying out innovative,  original ideas, thoughts and processes while trying to meet a need.  Creativity is not only important in the arts, but in the sciences and mathematics.
column84: The ability to find multiple approaches to solve a problem.
column85: Someone who finds beauty in the world around them.
column119: Rigid curriculum requirements, crowded curriculum, assessment criteria & standardised testing.    I will note that while standardised testing is a barrier, it can be an effective tool for planning,  teaching & creating school wide agreements for tackling whole school literacy and numeracy goals.  Until a better and cost effective alternative is made available it is better than nothing.
column132: Question 20 is very open to interpretation.  How do you measure creativity?  What does it look like in Science or Mathematics?  If someone is naturally creative in the arts are they naturally creative in the sciences?  If someone is analytical and able to find solutions to existing problems does that make them creative?

column82: Being able to use different ways to solve problems, present work etc. Having time to think about things and use strategies they have learned or come up with themselves.
column85: Able to think outside the square
column119: Having the time to do it without rushing kids. Trying to cover the curriculum, sometimes you just rush through it, trying to tick the boxes.

column82: Being able to accept a challenge, identify the alternatives and solve problems
column119: Curriculum demands  Time constraints  School culture  Assessment and reporting structures
column131: Creativity is part of faculty and professional development discussions as well as a part of task design

column132: You can't spell "occasionally"

column82: A personal demonstration of ones knowledge and expression
column119: recourses  funding  staff with a closed mindset  rigid curriculum

column82: thinking about things differently  using imagination  making things that are unique
column119: Students just wanting to be right

column82: Expressing an idea in a new way
column119: Time to prepare and conduct creative lessons.  Content driven curriculum.  Knowledge is valued higher than wisdom (applied knowledge)

column82: creativity means creating something unique. Creating could mean making, coming up with an idea
sense the gaps in collective perception and bash, mold, caress, construct ways and means to partially fill that gap.
column119: Expectations that the assessable components must be always quantifiable and inevitably statistically verifiable.    Teacher knows best    Creativity as a teaching method to simply  manifest the status quo ie to play out not play with an idea    Support at events where student creativity is showcased- exhibitions, performances, debates, problem solving challenges ie validate the risk taking
column131: Having said 'no' as it implies a formal training session; every exhibition or show or film or text read is fostering and fermenting the creative questions of how and why and better ways to reveal an idea or viewpoint which constantly helps me the teacher to reconsider my processes and methodologies . Best way to learn creativity is to visit events where such is showcased.
column132: The Oz Curriculum is trying to satisfy all, results in a codified and ultimately 'checklisted' approach to learning and has a greater tendency to stultify creativity not reward and encourage. Too much focus on the end not the process to that point.

column82: to improvise or be able to create original ideas
column119: Time factor in organising and developing creative activities

column82: An original approach to a task/problem or a suggestion that could help visual or hard copy learners.
column119: Students afraid of embarrassment or not doing well.  Grades- how will this task affect my grade?

column82: personal expression of (usually) visual communication
column83: deep awareness across a range of disciplines
column85: skillful manipulation of materials and media
column119: other curriculum constraints, timetable
column131: not sure what you mean

column35: Research Project, Science, Resource Based Learning across the curriculum
column82: Individual approach to a situation, exploring ideas.
column119: Time constraints, Traditional teaching styles, Busy Curriculum, Training of emerging teachers, Lack of expectation from Senior Leaders
column132: It's great this is being discussed, it is the 1st time I have ever seen it talked about.

column35: food technologies, textiles technologies, food and hospitality, child studies
column82: using a combination of ideas/resources in a non-prescribed way to solve a problem or make something new.
column83: open minded with their thinking and actions
column84: energised by taking risks with new situations, resources, problems
column85: able to work collaboratively with others, directly, indirectly can network
column119: I teach students food technologies in a general classroom and have one double a week when I can book them into the kitchen. Their familiarisations with the space is a barrier, as is the food ordering, pantry management of the budget. The time delay between ideas, plans, food production can be very drawn out and boring for us all.    Experience staff who are unwilling to contribute their time to collaboratively develop units/tasks courses beyond the time during faculty meetings. Leadership rather than faculty management should lead to better consistency and quality control intention would be beneficial.
column132: thanks for asking

column82: Thinking about and being able to do, create and see things in new and different ways. This is about thinking as well as doing.
column119: :Lack of teacher training in the range of strategies that can be used to both recognise and foster the development of creativity
column131: I have run them

column82: It varies depending on the context. I suspect it must involve some aspect of original thought, for the individual. It might of cause not be original but the process of developing a new paradigm is creative for the person.    In the classroom, this might involve a new approach to a task, a valid but unexpected interpretation, the improbable synthesis of two pedestrian views or just something they have researched but is exotically esoteric.

column119: Part of it is the cluttered curriculum, part is the fact that we, well I and many of my colleagues that I talk to, feel that the teacher work load is too high. Four years ago while my father-in-law was dying I dropped back to .8. Despite the cause there was an explosion of creativity in my work.    I noticed that when I had spare time I redesigned tasks, added new and different ITC sparkles, and generally found myself more passionate and enthused about my profession. I engaged with other teachers in different faculties and note that the year 8 students I taught in that year, who are now year 12s, have a closer and friendlier relationship with me than those from other years. As witnessed by the fact that a higher proportion of those I don't teach still seek me out to tell me of their successes and ask for help with work.    The second strand to the problem is that creativity is notoriously difficult to assess. The AC has I think tried to embed it within phrases like "Ability to effectively combine ideas, images and language from other texts to express ideas differently." However, "effectively" is not the same as "creatively." Since there is no explicit learning objective, it follows that it is not always as valued as it should be.
column131: I have attended many to develop my own creativity. There is an obvious transfer of skills and techniques.
column132: Encouraging opportunities for groups of teachers to share their ideas in a social atmosphere, with games and a clear spirit of "what if,  give it a go" or even ñfunî will do MUCH more for fostering creativity than rigidly prescriptive programs.   Despite the professions tendency to attract "controlaholics" as a group we don't like being compelled to do things. Part of the problem with the present drive to compel professional development and to regiment it is that what was fun is now a tedious chore. The need to meet and document certain standards encourages a mono-faculty attitude to T & D.

column119: The emphasis on testing and data collection every few weeks and The NAPLAN. Most tests are now online and multiple choice, which does not allow for individual answers or creativity. The importance given to the test results by the school, the parents and the education department. Children in Junior Primary school are no longer encouraged to play and be creative because we have too much pressure on us to make sure they can read at a certain level and know a certain number of sight words etc by the end of  the year. Creativity is born out of hard work and practice but not everyone is capable of successfully developing it - most are able to play though and the two are different things.
